thread.title: Appeal for Tasmanian soldier Teddy Sheean's Victoria Cross taken to British Admiralty - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Appeal for Tasmanian soldier Teddy Sheean's Victoria Cross taken to British Admiralty - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Emilie Gramenz
title: Appeal for Tasmanian soldier Teddy Sheean's Victoria Cross taken to British Admiralty - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
By Emilie Gramenz Posted February 25, 2017 13:55:19 Map: TAS 
An appeal for a Tasmanian soldier killed in a Japanese attack in World War II to be recognised with the Victoria Cross has been taken to the British Admiralty. 
Ordinary Seaman Teddy Sheean strapped himself to his gun as HMAS Armidale sunk in the Timor Sea in 1942. 
Ordered to abandon ship, he continued firing, bringing down one enemy bomber. 
His nephew, Garry Ivory, has been pushing for recognition for decades. 
He has now written a formal letter to the British Admiralty, co-signed by former Tasmanian senator and current state minister Guy Barnett. 
"My uncle's actions warrant a Victoria Cross because he gave his life to save his mates, and gave his life for his country, too," Mr Ivory said. 
"He had the chance to get away, he chose not to, and chose to go back and save his mates. 
"He was an Ordinary Seaman who did an extraordinary thing." 
Two years ago, Mr Ivory wrote a letter to Prince Harry highlighting his case. 
He said the response was very positive. 
"Teddy's action was under the British Admiralty at the time, and that's where we're going now," he said. 
"We're just hoping that they listen." 
Mr Ivory is expecting to hear back in about six months.
